poem:
"Epistles from a Man's Man"

Pugilist of prose, in letters, bared,
Macho myth of Hemingway quietly dared.
His pen, a matador's sword, slain despair,
His rough-edged tenderness dancing on air.
In words, both stark and feral, a creed,
Generosity the unseen seed,
With the best of the worst times, he'd lead
Sculpting life's pain into a masterpiece to read.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Generous and reflective’: letters show other sides to macho Ernest Hemingway He cultivated a hard-drinking macho image, with a taste for big-game hunting and a love of bullfighting, but Ernest Hemingway had a generous and thoughtful side that is revealed in previously unpublished letters. In the decade after he made his name with A Farewell to Arms, his 1929 war novel, his correspondence shows that he repeatedly offered advice and encouragement – as well as insights". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
